executiveSummary.title: Background & Context
executiveSummary.p1: The AMA Treaty was adopted by the AU Assembly on 11 February 2019 and entered into force on 5 November 2021 following the deposit of the 15th instrument of ratification. This marks the realisation of the AU's vision of a networked African medical products regulatory system.
executiveSummary.p2: The architecture is built around National Medicines Regulatory Authorities (NMRAs/NRAs), Regional Economic Communities (RECs) and their Medicines Regulatory Harmonization (MRH) programmes, and AMA as the continental apex body providing coordination, technical guidance, convergence tools and reliance platforms.
executiveSummary.p3: Currently, thirty-one (31) AU Member States are Party to the AMA Treaty. AMA is entering a decisive phase of operationalisation, and this Forum convenes Heads of NRAs and RECs Coordinators to establish practical working relationships for 2026.

background.title: Overall Goal
background.p1: To establish a shared vision and practical working relationship between AMA, Heads of NRAs and RECs coordinators around AMA's 2026 priorities – continental quality and safety monitoring, regulatory collaboration, digital systems, capacity building and support to local manufacturing.
background.p2: Each actor is expected to play a complementary role based on a clear division of labour, ensuring optimal use of resources, minimal duplication and evidence-based decision-making.

travelGuide.title: Welcome to the Land of a Thousand Hills
travelGuide.p1: Kigali is widely known as one of Africa's cleanest, safest, and most dynamic cities. As the host city for the HNRA Forum 2026, it offers a perfect blend of world-class infrastructure and authentic Rwandan culture.
travelGuide.p2: Rwanda has simplified its visa process, with many nationalities eligible for visa-on-arrival or easy e-visas, supporting its mission to be a hub for continental dialogue.
